text: Will be awesome if there would be a seat to be hired on a fully remote basis. I am still looking for any content marketing opportunity that will kickstart my career growth!

text:
Hello Superpath community!

We have a new "Dear Superpath" question. This is a way for folks to ask anonymous questions. 

Career stage: senior (8+ years)

"I'd love any tips from fellow Superpathers on how to provide constructive feedback to management on colleagues without making it personal or seemingly petty.

Background: We have a contractor who has been with us for several months and is increasingly steamrolling projects and lowering our close-knit team's morale with poor management skills (condescending tone, poor active listening, interrupting us during meetings, etc.).

Many of these interactions and events transpired while our team's manager was out on paternal leave. He's returned, and there are murmurs this contractor (who was supposed to leave at the end of Q3) may stay on our team for Q4, possibly as a full-time employee. *Many* colleagues and I have immense concerns about this, but we don't think our manager knows about just how debilitating this contractor's personality, work ethic, and communication skills have been. Upper management has only had good things to say about this contractor, although they are also not privy to the crummy treatment the rest of us get, or the additional work that gets piled onto our plates as a result.

I have a strong rapport with my manager and I feel comfortable going to him with these concerns, but I want to make sure the feedback on this contractor is objective and constructive. It is challenging to provide "facts" when so much of why this contractor is a poor addition to the team is in personal interactions and how we're treated. I would love any recommendations on how to reposition seemingly "personal" complaints into objective, task-oriented feedback."

i have unfortunately been on the manager side of a similar situation and i HUGELY appreciated the issues being brought to my attention because otherwise there's no way i could've known. and i have ZERO tolerance for jerks.

it's going to be hard to make this task-oriented if the tasks are on point but this person is just a jerk.

however, it's still so important to bring this to your manager's attention.

to keep things more objective, you can just make sure to stick to facts and real examples of what this person is saying/doing. also, if you're able to get others to talk to your manager about this person as well, then that would show that's it's not personal, but the whole team seeing the same thing.

luckily you have a good rapport with your manager so hopefully things will work out for you!! this type of situation is so stressful. best of luck to you.

text:
Radical transparency can be a tactic. If you're worried about coming off as personal or petty, then you can open up with something like:

"I'm worried about what I'm about to tell you might seem petty or personal, but it's coming from a genuine and objective place."

[assume that you get a positive, empathetic response and an invitation to continue...]

"Here's the thing. [Contractor]'s personality has been a huge issue for the team. I have examples I can share and [others] will back me up. We're all quite fearful that [contractor] will be made part of the team full time in Q4."

//

This gets right to the point and pulls no punches and hopefully sets the stage properly.

text: If you haven’t already, I would begin documenting specific behaviors/incidents and ask other concerned team members to do the same. Bad personal interactions are facts … once they are documented.

elements.text: If you haven’t already, I would begin documenting specific behaviors/incidents and ask other concerned team members to do the same. Bad personal interactions are facts … once they are documented.

text:
The managers and directors at our org went through LifeLabs Learning training recently. One thing they taught us was about giving constructive feedback, specifically using a tool call the “Micro Yes,” which is just a way of saying “get buy-in.”

When you talk to your manager, consider using this type of feedback framework to make sure you get buy-in, and that you’re reducing mystery, showing examples/documentation, and proposing a path forward.

Your situation seems familiar to some of the scenarios we discussed in this training.

As others said here ^^ make sure you have specific examples/facts. When you can deblur a statement like “poor management skills” with an example, your manager has no choice but to take you and your team’s concerns seriously. Good luck navigating this stressful situation.

<https://justworks.com/blog/how-to-give-effective-feedback-your-colleagues>

attachments.title: How to Give Better Constructive Feedback to Your Colleagues | Justworks
attachments.text: Ready to overcome your fear of giving feedback? Here’s your step-by-step guide for giving better feedback to your teammates.

The managers and directors at our org went through LifeLabs Learning training recently. One thing they taught us was about giving constructive feedback, specifically using a tool call the “Micro Yes,” which is just a way of saying “get buy-in.”

When you talk to your manager, consider using this type of feedback framework to make sure you get buy-in, and that you’re reducing mystery, showing examples/documentation, and proposing a path forward.

Your situation seems familiar to some of the scenarios we discussed in this training.

As others said here ^^ make sure you have specific examples/facts. When you can deblur a statement like “poor management skills” with an example, your manager has no choice but to take you and your team’s concerns seriously. Good luck navigating this stressful situation.

text:
Completely agree on documenting specific incidents!

based on my previous experience, I'd also say that it's important to be very clear and direct about how you/your team members have been feeling — when I had an issue like this I definitely doubted my own feelings quite a bit and I think that led me not to convey just how bad the issue was to my manager because I also didn't want to seem like the jerk :sweat_smile:

something else that can help is, since you've said other people also feel this way, encouraging them to speak independently to your manager as well. the more people who feel comfortable sharing their experiences, the better - that way it's very clear it's not just an isolated incident that you have but rather something that the whole team is experiencing. power and strength in numbers!

best of luck to you and your team though - having been there I know just how difficult it is to go through something like that.

text: additionally, has anyone said any of this directly to the contractor as well? I know that can be intimidating (and from what you've said probably wouldn't help), but it also helps to be able to say something to your manager like "I've already talked to them about their behaviour in a constructive way and it wasn't well received" or anything like that — just to show that you're not trying to pass the blame and genuinely want to create a good team environment with open communication.
